Speak no evil is a blast from start to finish. A family-holiday-suspense-thriller this film puts you in the front seat from the get go. It‚Äôs basically ‚Äúget out‚Äù but with a family who are trapped, taken hostage by a sociopathic couple. Director James Watkins delivers a nerve-biting film that lets you get up close and personal with its leads. Essentially the story is about a couple who are trying to work on their marriage whilst on vacation but take their personal problems with them. The message or lesson behind the story is very clear. When you are in a vulnerable state in life, never let people especially strangers take advantage of you. Protect yourself at all times. Watkins keeps a tight focus on the protagonist‚Äôs and their new found friends. Never allowing the story to drift off into absurdity but rather insanity. The country house setting is claustrophobic, as each moment passes we feel the walls and spaces getting smaller and smaller. The film cleverly builds up to the moment of truth. Can the married couple escape in time or is there more at stake? James Mcavoy is outrageously enthralling. He needs to play more villains. Such an energetic performance and a very good script that has enough room for subtleties making the characters feel as fleshed out as possible. As to be expected the climax is a game of cat and mouse, hide and seek but it never feels too silly or far-fetched. Watkins‚Äôs mixes the right amount of violence, misdirection and foreplay wrapping things up with sheer consequence. Speak no evil is a well crafted stalker-thriller that packs an emotional gut punch too. If anything else this is wild entertainment at its best.

The film follows a family consisting of Louise (Mackenzie Davis), Ben (Scott), and Agnes (Alex West), who, while on vacation, meet another family led by Chiara (Aislinn Franciose) and Dan Hough (Ant). At first, they seem welcoming, but their true sinister intentions soon emerge. Ant tries to warn Agnes about the danger, but since Chiara and James McAvoy have cut his tongue, he struggles to communicate. This tension immerses the audience in the same frustration as the character. With outstanding performances, especially from James McAvoy and Dan Hough, the film delivers an intriguing suspense story, despite some predictable moments. The shocking ending reveals that Ant was kidnapped and that this family had done the same to others before. Overall, it‚Äôs a great choice for suspense lovers.

A very strong performance from James McAvoy carries this film beyond the riff raff of popcorn horror. Often in horror films we wonder why the heroes make the choices they do. To go into the house that seems haunted or creepy, to linger when they ought to be fleeing, to trust obviously creepy villains. And this film was full of moments like that. The married couple who have a middle-school aged daughter make many bad decisions and it causes us, the audience, to stop caring. But we keep watching to see McAvoy's mesmerizing turn here. His charm hides abusive and psychotic tendencies that gradually reveal themselves throughout the movie and it's very interesting to see just how far he goes into nutsburgers crazytown. And he really goes there. A decent movie if you're looking for a thrill anchored by a strong actor acting strongly!

There is an increasing sense of dread juxtaposed with the lush holiday villa and pretty English countryside. It is hard to care about the annoying, stupid, and weak American couple and their weird daughter thanks to their many "as if" moments. I wish the writers had given them more likeable qualities. The real horror part of this suspense movie is demonstrated through child abuse and not the "twist" that viewers can predict. I couldn't finish watching the original Speak No Evil when it came out in 2022, because it is so much darker than this remake. Knowing that the endings are vastly different, I'm more comfortable with this Hollywood ending, but it could be disappointing to true horror fans.

Speak No Evil highlights the pitfalls of remaking a film without capturing its original essence. In essence, while The Guests is a masterclass in restrained psychological horror, Speak No Evil feels like an attempt to replicate its success without understanding the subtlety and cultural context that made the original work.

I was hesitant about watching this one. It's a remake of the Danish thriller Speak No Evil, which came out just two years ago and holds the title of the creepiest and scariest film I‚Äôve ever seen. As a horror fan always seeking a challenge, the original Speak No Evil left an indelible mark on me‚Äînot because it was traditionally scary, but because of its sheer realism and how relatable the characters felt. Having loved the original and considering it one of my favorite horror films, I was skeptical about the remake. The only reason I decided to give it a chance was the stellar cast, especially James McAvoy, whose portrayal of the antagonist intrigued me. The first half of the film genuinely surprised me, delivering a deeply unsettling and gripping psychological thriller much like the original. It masterfully delves into themes of fear, guilt, and moral dilemmas, with a narrative that steadily builds tension and suspense. Its slow-burn approach creates a truly immersive experience, where every interaction feels loaded with hidden menace. I was filled with respect for how it honored the original while, in some instances, offering even more terrifying portrayals that outshone the first film. This is where my fears about the film were realized. The "Americanization" began to shine through, stripping away the darkness and ambiguity that made the original so compelling. As the film progressed, it started unraveling, answering too many of the questions that made the original so haunting. In my eyes, the sheer terror created by the unseen and the unexplained was what made the original a masterpiece. Unfortunately, the final 20 minutes devolve into a typical Hollywood horror movie with a somewhat happy ending‚Äîa stark departure from the bleak, twisted conclusion of the original. The cheesiness set in like an American hamburger, turning what could have been a dark and faithful adaptation into just another formulaic horror flick. This departure from the elegance of its first half ultimately left the film feeling like a mishmash, ordinary rather than great. The acting was phenomenal, with James McAvoy delivering a truly terrifying and maniacal performance as Paddy. His portrayal is packed with emotional depth and nuance, seamlessly shifting between vulnerability and intense menace, making his character both raw and complex. The minor in the film. Dan Hough's performance as Ant is compelling and memorable and one that I think does better for me than the original, the character seems to have more screentime resulting in him being much more relatable to the viewer as compared to the original . The cinematography and grainy picture quality added a distinct edge to the film, enhancing its realism and amplifying its unsettling atmosphere. The slow, deliberate shots and meticulously designed sets contributed to the overall discomfort, grounding the story in a sense of authenticity. While some moments felt slightly over-engineered, the sets consistently upheld the film's overarching vibe, complementing its eerie tone effectively. For me, the American remake of Speak No Evil starts off strong, capturing the unsettling vibe of the original with a gripping first half and stellar performances‚Äîespecially from James McAvoy. But it loses steam in the final act, swapping the haunting ambiguity of the Danish film for a typical Hollywood ending. While it‚Äôs still a decent watch with solid cinematography, it doesn‚Äôt quite live up to the dark brilliance of the original and doesn‚Äôt compare to what I considered one of the scariest films I‚Äôve ever seen. 8/10

2024's 'Speak No Evil' is probably the years' best grounded horror film. SYNOPSIS: 'A family is invited to spend a whole weekend in a lonely home in the countryside, but as the weekend progresses, they realize that a dark side lies within the family who invited them.' Often remakes of European horror films lose something from the original material and fade into nothingness. But that's not the case here. There's no 'been there, done that' here as James McAvoy absolutely excels in this role and literally holds nothing back. His gritty and unhinged performance is completely mesmerising and overall makes this film something very special. It's 'real', it could happen. 'Speak No Evil' is a twisted, suspenseful experience that keeps you engaged despite being a slow burn of a movie. This is a psychological thriller that lies in wait for its audience, and when you least suspect it, it goes in for the kill. Exceptional. 9/10

Speak No Evil: When Politeness Becomes Deadly! In an era where horror films often rush to shock without substance, ‚ÄúSpeak No Evil‚Äù stands apart by playing a more sophisticated game with its audience. Director James Watkins knows we see the threat coming ‚Äì that‚Äôs part of his strategy. Like a cat toying with a mouse, he lets us watch his characters walk into an obvious trap, making us willing participants in their downfall. The setup might seem familiar: Ben and Louise Dalton, Americans living in London and struggling with marital issues, decide to take a much-needed break with their 12-year-old daughter, Agnes, at a beautiful Italian resort. Ben, dealing with the sting of a recent job demotion, hopes the trip will bring some relief. At the resort, they meet Paddy, a charismatic English doctor with an overly friendly, almost alarming demeanor, along with his intense wife, Ciara, and their young son, Ant, who has a distinctive speech impediment due to a malformed tongue. What starts as casual vacation friendship takes an unexpected turn when Paddy extends an invitation to their countryside home in England. When the Daltons return to London, they‚Äôre surprised to receive a follow-up letter from Paddy, insisting they visit. With their marriage showing cracks and hoping a weekend getaway might help, Ben convinces Louise to accept. The idyllic English countryside setting soon becomes a backdrop for mounting psychological tension as the Daltons find themselves caught in an increasingly uncomfortable situation. What begins as mere social awkwardness gradually transforms into something far more sinister, forcing Ben and Louise to confront not only their hosts‚Äô true intentions but also their own inability to break free from the constraints of social politeness ‚Äì even when their survival instincts are screaming at them to run. As their weekend retreat spirals into a psychological nightmare, the Daltons must decide how much social courtesy is worth when the cost might be their lives. Watkins takes unusual care in crafting his characters‚Äô backgrounds. Unlike the current trend of horror films with one-dimensional characters, here the characters get a proper backstory. Ben‚Äôs recent job demotion, Louise‚Äôs suppressed frustrations, even minor characters receive careful attention. Some might call this excessive, but it serves a crucial purpose: making their inevitable doom more than just a horror movie payoff ‚Äì it becomes a tragedy we‚Äôre invested in. Mackenzie Davis brings remarkable depth to Louise, portraying her with a humble, genuine touch that feels instantly relatable to viewers. Her performance captures a woman caught between her instincts and the social conventions that keep her in increasingly uncomfortable situations. Davis conveys a subtle awareness of the danger around her, yet her character is restrained by the same unspoken rules that bind many people in real life. Scoot McNairy, as Ben, nails the role of the passive husband who avoids conflict at all costs, creating tension as his desire to escape confrontation leaves his family vulnerable. James McAvoy‚Äôs Paddy, meanwhile, is not just a typical antagonist‚Äîhe‚Äôs a predator who is skillfully preying his way into his victims‚Äô lives with unsettling ease. McAvoy‚Äôs portrayal of Paddy adds layers of menace to the film, showing a character who understands the impact of silent social. The horror here works on multiple levels. Yes, there‚Äôs the surface threat of strange people with unclear intentions, but the deeper terror comes from watching social pressure become a prison. Every polite laugh, every swallowed objection, every moment of silence where someone should speak up but doesn‚Äôt ‚Äì these are the real horror elements, made more powerful because we recognize them from our own lives. As the film progresses, Watkins maintains suspense through careful pacing and subtle escalation. Unlike many contemporary horror films that rely on jump scares and gore, ‚ÄúSpeak No Evil‚Äù builds its dread through the accumulation of small violations of social norms. Each transgression is just slight enough that objecting would seem ruder than the offense itself ‚Äì a masterful representation of how social pressure can trap us. The third act‚Äôs violent eruption might seem jarring to viewers who expected the psychological chess game to maintain its subtle dance until the end. Some critics argue that abandoning the film‚Äôs careful exploration of social dynamics for more visceral horror betrays its thoughtful premise. Yet there‚Äôs a brutal logic to this shift ‚Äì like a volcano that has been quietly building pressure beneath a serene surface, the explosion of violence feels both sudden and inevitable. The film‚Äôs descent into overt horror isn‚Äôt a departure from its psychological foundation but rather its natural conclusion ‚Äì when social pressure reaches a critical point, the explosion isn‚Äôt just loud, it‚Äôs devastating. Like a kettle that must eventually whistle or a spring that must release its tension, the ending‚Äôs brutality serves as the only possible outcome for characters who‚Äôve compressed their survival instincts beneath layers of social obligation for so long. It‚Äôs not that the film abandons its themes of social pressure and politeness ‚Äì rather, it shows us their ultimate, terrible cost. Speak No Evil is a layered horror experience that bypasses cheap jump scares in favor of unsettling psychological tension, it succeeds in showcasing that effective horror comes not from monsters or gore, but from how what we consider harmless social norms‚Äîlike politeness and keeping the peace‚Äîcan actually lead us into danger. This fresh take is perfect for a horror film, showing how ordinary manners can become traps that others exploit. Speak No Evil could be a memorable entry in the genre. However, the familiar twist ending may feel predictable for some, taking away a bit from its psychological depth in favor of more conventional scares.

IN A NUTSHELL: The story is about a family that is invited to spend a whole weekend in a country home of another couple they had recently met while on vacation. The weekend reveals startling lies and an unimaginable dark side. This is an American remake of the 2022 Danish film. It‚Äôs unusual to get an American adaptation of a film so quickly! The movie was directed by James Watkins who also cowrote it with Christian Tafdrup and Mads Tafdrup. Christian and his brother co-wrote the screenplay, while Christian directed it. James McAvoy said that he did not watch the Danish film before he began filming because he didn‚Äôt want it to influence how he performed and presented the story. Twenty-four hours after they finished filming, he watched the original and said he was extremely impressed. Just so you know, the original Danish version is much more violent and brutal. The director of the unsettling Danish movie revealed that a real-life experience he had inspired the film. He and his wife met a Dutch couple when they were on vacation. Later, that couple invited them to visit them in the Netherlands. He and his wife declined the invitation because they thought it would be awkward. He let his mind wander and explore the worse-case scenario to see how far and horrific this movie could go. THINGS I LIKED: I don‚Äôt really like horror movies, so the only reason I wanted to watch this was to see the incredibly sinister performance by James McAvoy. I‚Äôve been a huge fan of his and knew he would be amazing in this. The‚Äôs absolutely nothing he could have done better in this role. His creepy performance was stellar. The rest of the cast also did a great job and includes Mackenzie Davis, Scoot McNairy, Aisling Franciosi, and the two darling kid actors: Alix West Lefler and Dan Hough. There are so many times in Acts 1 and 2 where we see red flags and feel extremely uncomfortable. As you become more aware of what‚Äôs really happening, you want to yell at the screen to warn the characters not to do what they‚Äôre about to do. That‚Äôs what a good horror can do: evoke fear and passion in the audience. Mission accomplished in this film. The movie was filmed in Gloucester, England and also in Croatia for a week. The title takes on an interesting meaning in several ways. Because you know the madness is coming, you feel the tension from the very beginning of the film and throughout every scene, wondering when the chaos will begin. The dialogue does a great job injecting some humor along the way. THINGS I DIDN‚ÄôT LIKE: Fans of the original Danish movie might be disappointed that the American film changes some plot points, especially the ending. Like most horror movies, there are always characters who make dumb decisions that put themselves in even more danger. Some viewers might complain that the story is slow-moving because they want to get to the crazy action sooner. The horror begins at the last 20 minutes of the movie. Sometimes, it was hard to understand what everyone was saying. TIPS FOR PARENTS: This frightening film is inappropriate for kids. Bloody, brutal violence Profanity Talk of a girl‚Äôs period Talk of divorce Stealing Portrayal of intimate relationships (fully clothed under a table) To see my full review, go to my Movie Review Mom YouTube channel!

A couple from London befriends another couple during a vacation in Italy. After returning home, they are invited to pass some time with the new friends at their remote farmhouse. Once there, the hosts reveal an awkward and sometimes outrageous behaviour, creating in their guests an enormous discomfort. The true reason behind this invitation goes above and beyond the imagination of the darkest mind. "Speak No Evil" is a remake of the 2022 Danish movie with the same title, though it reinvents the final act in a surprising way. The movie creates an eerie discomfort in the viewer by simply subverting some social conventions. The level of tension grows slowly until it culminates in an explosive and violent finale.

Smart, warm, funny father turns out to be a psycho serial killer. That's the basic premise of this movie. It doesn't suprise that the first part of the movie is how this eventual killer tries hard to fake a friendly, normal facade in order to lure his victims. But soon, the questions keep kicking in. For example, how you can spend hours and days with another person/family without truly learning something about them in the process? How self-obsessed must you be? So, the killer managed to lure his potential victims into his den. Well deserved, I say. Keeping in mind what his ultimate goal is, there is simply no reason whatsoever to keep them around. And yet, so much unnecessary drama ensues just to keep us on our toes (I guess). When it's just infurious to watch them all act unbelievably stupid and ignorant. I don't want to spoil it for anyone so I'm just going to say, what happens in the final 15 minutes of the movie, is so out of character particularly for one person that it just got ridiculous. The problem is not the acting, though, it's really the script. I think McAvoy did a great job, in principle, and I hope to see him in better movies.

‚ÄúSpeak No Evil,‚Äù directed by James Watkins, is a masterful psychological thriller that expertly unravels the intricacies of human relationships and the unsettling consequences of misplaced trust. This film captivates its audience with an atmosphere of tension and dread, making it a standout entry in the genre. The story revolves around an American family‚ÄîBen, Louise, and their daughter Agnes‚Äîwho unknowingly step into a nightmare after befriending a seemingly charming Dutch couple. From the moment the family arrives at the couple‚Äôs remote estate, the film plunges viewers into a chilling exploration of social discomfort and moral ambiguity. Watkins skillfully builds a sense of unease, showcasing how politeness can mask sinister intentions. The performances in ‚ÄúSpeak No Evil‚Äù are exceptional. The lead actors bring depth and authenticity to their roles, particularly in portraying the emotional struggle of a family caught in a web of manipulation and terror. Their gradual realization of the danger they face is palpable, making their plight all the more relatable and horrifying. Visually, the film is striking. The idyllic beauty of the countryside stands in stark contrast to the malevolence that unfolds, heightening the sense of horror. Watkins‚Äôs direction allows for a slow, deliberate build-up of tension, leading to a climactic finale that is both shocking and thought-provoking. The film navigates dark themes with a deft hand, balancing moments of levity with the ever-present undercurrent of dread. One of the film‚Äôs greatest strengths is its ability to provoke thought. It raises important questions about complicity and the lengths to which individuals will go to maintain social niceties, even in the face of overt discomfort. The exploration of these themes resonates long after the credits roll, prompting viewers to reflect on their own experiences with trust and social boundaries. Overall, ‚ÄúSpeak No Evil‚Äù is a powerful and unsettling film that leaves a lasting impression. Its blend of psychological horror, strong performances, and incisive commentary on human behavior make it a must-see for fans of the genre. Three fourths of this movie is dialogue, walking and feeling the weird behavior of this family that us, the audience, know is not trustworthy. But the tension and edge feeling that this type of horror gives you is simply natural, because it has happened before, and it is real. So this movie really makes the effort to make it the most believable possible, and it works. People lurking in the background, messages trying to be sent but failing and ultimately just really high tension. It really puts you in the place of the protagonists and explains to you why they‚Äôre doing what they are doing. But, as always in this type of movie, huge mistakes that no one in the right mind would make, are made, and although the movie does a good job of soothing you back into the plot and making it feel fresh again, it just keeps bashing in your head: ‚Äúwhy didn‚Äôt they do this, or that‚Ä¶‚Äù and this type of questioning gets you out of the film, because it breaks the connection that it kept so long trying to form. In the end, the final act really feels rushed, with too much going on, but it works, because the movie isn‚Äôt about those scenes, it‚Äôs about the realism of its plot and characters, and that it can, mostly, handle very well.

Speak No Evil (2024) is an intense, psychological thriller that masterfully combines tension, fear, and a gripping moral dilemma, making it one of the standout horror films of the year. Directed by James Watkins, the movie delivers a nerve-wracking experience from start to finish, leaving audiences on the edge of their seats. The film excels in building suspense through its minimalist approach. Rather than relying on jump scares, Speak No Evil creates a slow burn of dread, reminiscent of "Funny Games", using uncomfortable social interactions and sinister undertones to make the viewer squirm. The performances, especially from the lead actors, are outstanding. Their portrayal of seemingly normal people in increasingly disturbing circumstances adds a chilling layer of realism to the film. What makes Speak No Evil particularly effective is its exploration of human nature. It raises thought-provoking questions about politeness, boundaries, and the lengths people will go to avoid confrontation, even at their own peril. The film is not just a horror story but a disturbing commentary on the darker sides of social norms. If you're a fan of psychological horror that lingers long after the credits roll, Speak No Evil is a must-watch. The cast delivers powerhouse performances, bringing an eerie authenticity to the increasingly disturbing scenarios. The leads, in particular, masterfully capture the emotional and psychological unraveling of their characters. Their portrayal of fear, confusion, and desperation feels so natural that it becomes hard to separate the actors from their roles. They maintain a delicate balance between vulnerability and tension, making us feel every ounce of dread and discomfort the characters experience. What makes the acting so striking is how it enhances the film‚Äôs slow-burn horror. Rather than relying on traditional scare tactics, the performances build an overwhelming sense of dread through subtle, nuanced interactions. Even in quiet moments, the cast conveys an undercurrent of unease, leaving viewers constantly on edge, waiting for the inevitable horror to unfold. The chemistry between the actors is palpable, which makes the escalating tension in the story all the more effective. As their characters‚Äô lives spiral out of control, the actors convey this descent with such skill that the viewer feels both emotionally invested and terrified for them. Overall, Speak No Evil is a haunting and unforgettable thriller, largely thanks to its superb acting. The cast's gripping performances ensure that the film not only keeps you hooked but also leaves a lasting impact long after the credits roll.

What kind of kills the movie's plot is how there were multiple times I grew frustrated with the characters not making the obvious choice. The movie has a very slow build-up, but towards the third act, it becomes more intense and gripping. Unlike the original Danish film, where the family simply let the villains do violent things to them, the characters in this American remake fought back and showed a strong will to survive. This contrast was quite striking; the original film's portrayal of the family's lack of survival instinct was frustrating, leading up to a very disturbing and shocking ending. In contrast, the American version was just nuts. I found myself clapping, cheering, and yelling because the scenes were so intense that I was on the edge of my seat. It also made me realize that excessive kindness and politeness can literally put you in danger. As a people pleaser myself, it hit me that I should start setting boundaries to avoid dangerous situations. Overall, the movie is really great. It has moments of humor and is engaging throughout. It's a shame that no one talks about it. It‚Äôs very underrated; there were only about five people in the theater. Hopefully, word of mouth will pick up because this movie deserved better at the box office. üôå
